of the United States Paris October 5th 1882 Sir, On or about the 16th of February last the Captian of the French gunboat "Marabout" acting under orders, destroyed by setting them on fire, certain establishment of the African natives on the Gaboon River. One of the esetablishment burned was an out station of the American Presbyterian mission situated on
His Excellency Mr. E. Duchie President of the Council Ministor of Foregin Affairs Paris
Nigenengue or Ningue Island The "Marabout" it is time . fire to the property of the Mission But its hostile course aroused of the native tribes, who reached Ningue-Ningue, after the deployment of the Gunboat, broke into the building of the Mission and olundered everything it contained. The members of the American Mission who are represented by the Rev. Mr. Walker, had no opportunity of saving their property. They were not notified in advance by the French Authorities of any intended hostilities against the natives, and, to their knowledge the inhabitants of Ningue-Ningue had committed no act which could have given them reason to suppose thath any such action was contemplated. It appears that some time begore the destruction of this village, the Captain of the Gunboat declared that there was no intention of proceeding against its people. It cannot I think be claimed that the French Authorities are not responsible for the destruction of the Mission, as the natives would certainly, never have resorted to violence and plunder if war had not been waged against them. During the 30 years the Mission has existed in Gaboon it has enjoyed the friendship of the natives, who were often left alone in charge of the building and property. In presence of these facts the American Mission of Gaboon claims an indemnity of three thousand five hundred francs (3500. frs) for the loss sustained in consequence of the action of the French authorities of the Colony, and I am instructed by my Government to lay this claim before your Excellency? The amount of property destroyed is of no consequence to a Government like Grance, but it is a large amount for poor clergymen who have exiled themselves in a distant and uncivilized land for the cause of religion and morality. At the time of this unpleasant incident, the Rev. Mr. Walker, speaking in the name of the Mission, applied to Captain Clerin Commanding the Colony for the indemnity which is here claimed. But this officer, through replying thath the claim would be submitted to the proper authority seems to have misunderstood its real foundation and true character. I cannot believe that the French Government after a full examination of the facts will adopt the defence outlined byh Commandant Clerin thath the Mission station trespassed upon French Territory, as such contention would not effect the nature of the claim. The simple question of issue seems to be whether the Mission station was pillaged by hostile navtives in consequence of the destruction ordered by the French Authorities and if this destruction was called for by such an emergency og self defense as would prevent warning to non combattants. In the latter case the French Government will, doubtless, of its own accord, lender indemnification to these worthy men, who, since their esstablishment in Gaboon more than a quarter of a century ago have held the most cordial relations with the Colonial Authorities and have been a powerful adjunct to the civilizing and moral tendencies of French rule on this part of the African Coast. I avail myself of this occasion to renew the assurance of the distinguished consideration with which I have the honor to be. Your Excellency's Most obedient servant L.P. Morton
